The whole point of this post was to point out that anorexia manifests itself all around the world in different circumstances. It is a disease of the mind, and is seen EVERYWHERE, much like schizophrenia. It is not just exclusive to "first world" countries where "spoiled children are just refusing to eat" and the comparisons are COMPLETELY relevant to each other.
Anorexia is classified when a person maintains a low body weight and there is refusal to gain sufficient weight. Usually, this is accompanied by some kind of traumatic experience that made the individual feel a loss of control in their lives and empowered or satisfied by a restrictive consumption of food.
In either case, the individual is not eating because s/he is not capable of giving up the control they feel from restricting their food intake. Those people in Africa who do not eat, despite having food around them are in fact ANOREXIC. They have experienced an extremely traumatic event where they felt an immense loss of control and now, it is reflective in their consumption habits.
This is exactly the same as someone who is experiencing anorexia in, let's say the U.S. Something happens, causes the person to feel a loss of control in their lives, the person responds by restricting their food intake in order to feel as though they have control in their lives.
In fact, most mental illnesses follow this pattern. There is a genetic predisposition to the mental disorder, a stressor causes the illness to be induced and the recovery from the illness is along and grueling process. This is especially true of adults with anorexia, where relapse rates are extremely high.
The point is, anorexia is a mental illness, much like every other mental illness and just like we don't blame people for having schizophrenia, we shouldn't blame them for having anorexia.

WRITING.TITLE: To the people who believe people who CHOOSE to have anorexia
WRITING.TEXT:
Eating disorders are a REAL mental illness. In anorexia nervosa the person typically has a chaotic sense of control in their life and seek to satisfy their feeling of control via food restriction. Eating disorders generally have very little to do with people not "counting their blessings" that they have food to eat and more to do with emotional and mental problems from current or past traumatic experiences.
Like almost every other mental illness, people with anorexia nervosa DO have delusions. Their brain actually tricks them into perceiving themselves as fatter than they are when they look in the mirror. Their brain's dangerous sense of perfectionism is extremely self destructive as they try to persistently lose more and more weight.
People with anorexia also have low amounts of serotonin (an important hormone in mood regulation) and have high co-morbid rates with depression. Anorexia nervosa has the highest death rate amongst all of the eating disorders, with patients usually killing themselves or dying from complications from a very low body weight. This mental illness is no joke, and saying you should just "be glad you have good food to eat" oversimplifies the entire disorder.
Also, it's not a first world problem. In parts of Africa, where starvation is rampant, it is seen in children and families when food is reintroduced into the household, the family members still refuse to eat or gain a healthy amount of weight.
After WW2, victims of concentration camps also had the same problem with gaining sufficient weight after being starved and having access to enough food.
These instances show us that anorexia can be induced and is certainly not something that spoiled "first world" people CHOOSE to do. It is a mental illness, where the brain and mind and the body affect the behavior of an individual to the point of self destruction.
Think about that next time you make ignorant statements about something you have no idea about.
